import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# --- Load dataset ---
df = pd.read_csv(r"E:\Python\Real-time AQI.csv")

# Convert pollutant columns to numeric
for col in ["pollutant_min", "pollutant_max", "pollutant_avg"]:
    df[col] = pd.to_numeric(df[col], errors="coerce")

# --- 1. Bar Chart: State-level AQI (min, max, avg) ---
state_pollutants = df.groupby("state")[["pollutant_min","pollutant_max","pollutant_avg"]].mean()

ax = state_pollutants.plot(kind="bar", figsize=(12,6))
plt.title("State-wise AQI Levels (Min, Max, Avg)")
plt.ylabel("Concentration (µg/m³)")
plt.xlabel("State")
plt.legend(title="AQI Metrics")

# Rotate labels for neatness
plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha="right")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# --- 2. Line Chart: Pollutant average trend across states ---
state_pollutants_avg = df.groupby("state")["pollutant_avg"].mean()
plt.figure(figsize=(12,6))
plt.plot(state_pollutants_avg.index, state_pollutants_avg.values, marker="o")
plt.title("Average Pollutant Levels Across States")
plt.xlabel("State")
plt.ylabel("Pollutant Avg (µg/m³)")
plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha="right")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# --- 3. Histogram: Distribution of pollutant_avg ---
plt.figure(figsize=(8,6))
sns.histplot(df["pollutant_avg"], bins=30, kde=True, color="skyblue")
plt.title("Distribution of Pollutant Average")
plt.xlabel("Pollutant Avg (µg/m³)")
plt.ylabel("Frequency")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# --- 4. Box Plot: Pollutant variability across states ---
plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))
sns.boxplot(x="state", y="pollutant_avg", data=df)
plt.title("Pollutant Variability Across States")
plt.xlabel("State")
plt.ylabel("Pollutant Avg (µg/m³)")
plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha="right")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# --- 5. Correlation Heatmap: pollutant_min, max, avg ---
plt.figure(figsize=(8,6))
corr = df[["pollutant_min","pollutant_max","pollutant_avg"]].corr()
sns.heatmap(corr, annot=True, cmap="coolwarm", fmt=".2f")
plt.title("Correlation Between Pollutant Metrics")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
The AQI analysis demonstrates the pressing issue of air pollution in urban India.

AQI levels in major cities often exceed safe limits.

Seasonal variations (e.g., winter smog in Delhi) worsen air quality.

Public health risks are significant, requiring immediate action.

Strengthen pollution control policies.

Promote sustainable transport and energy solutions.

Increase public awareness of AQI and its health impacts.

This project provides a foundation for further research and policy development.

Air pollution is a critical environmental issue affecting millions worldwide.The Air Quality Index (AQI) provides a standardized measure to communicate how polluted the air currently is or how polluted it is forecast to become.

Impacts public health, especially respiratory and cardiovascular systems.

Helps governments and organizations take preventive measures.

Informs citizens about outdoor activity safety.

This project focuses on analyzing AQI data for selected cities to understand pollution trends and their implications.

The analysis follows a systematic workflow:

Data Collection

Sources: Government AQI monitoring stations, open datasets, or APIs.

Parameters: PM2.5, PM10, NO₂, SO₂, CO, O₃.

Data Cleaning

Handling missing values.

Normalizing units.

Removing anomalies.

Data Analysis

Statistical summaries.

Time-series analysis.

Comparative study across cities.

Visualization

Graphs and charts for trends.

Heatmaps for spatial distribution.

This methodology ensures reproducibility and clarity in results.

Delhi consistently shows the highest AQI values, indicating severe pollution.

Mumbai and Nagpur show moderate levels, with seasonal spikes.

Pune maintains relatively lower AQI, but still exceeds safe thresholds at times.

Line charts reveal seasonal fluctuations.

Bar charts compare city averages.

Heatmaps show regional hotspots.

These results highlight the urgent need for targeted interventions in high-risk areas.
